 1. BACKGROUND A. COUNTRY ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL SITUATION 1.1 Growth and development in Vietnam is in transition. Emerging from the Soviet influence of the 1980's, Vietnam is changing from a centralized, largely controlled socialist economy to one that is primarily market driven. Despite a period of successful macroeconomic reforms, Vietnam remains a densely populated and poor country largely dependent on natural resources for its economic well-being. Per capita income in Vietnam, estimated at less than US$250 per annum, makes it one of the poorest countries in the world. Rural poverty is estimated at 57 percent, more than double the 26 percent rate for the urban areas. With about 80 percent of its approximate population of 75 million living in the rural areas, Vietnam is very dependent on its agriculture and natural resources, which account for almost 30 percent of GDP and 60 percent of merchandise exports. Approximately 73 percent of the total labor force is employed in the sector, and this dependency and the high population pressure on scarce arable land are exerting tremendous pressure on the country's natural resource base. B. THE NATURAL RESOURCE AND ENVIRONMENT SITUATION 1.2 One of Vietnam's primary natural resources is forests. Vietnam's natural forest cover has declined from 67 percent of total land area in the 1940s to roughly 26 percent (1993). The total area of natural forests has been declining at an estimated average rate of 350,000 hectare (ha) per year in recent years. Of the 19 million ha of land currently classified as forest land, some 13 million ha is largely denuded former forests with low agricultural productivity and is twice the area under existing cultivation. Only 1.0 million ha contain medium to rich quality forests. These forests contain a wealth of plant species, many of which are endemic, confined to small geographical ranges, and occur in low numbers. Of the world's identified vascular plants, 10 percent are believed to be endemic to Vietnam. These forests also contain the highest avian and primate diversity in mainland Southeast Asia. Within the past two years, two new mammal species, the Vu Quang Ox and the Giant Muntjac (a deer) were discovered in the upland forest of two Central Highland provinces. Before these discoveries, only three other mammals had been discovered in this century (Okapi in Zaire in 1906, Kouprey in Indochina in 1937, and Chocoan Peccary in Paraguay in 1975). Many scientists believe that the potential for more new discoveries remains high particularly in the border areas with Cambodia and Lao PDR.
 - 2 - 1.3 The leading cause of forest land degradation (shifting cultivation and arable land expansion) are primarily attributable to population pressure'. Population growth has been the highest in the north where the land per unit of rural population is 0.06 ha (compared to the national average of 0.13 ha, which already ranks among the lowest in the world); the natural population growth rate is about 3.0 percent per annum; and forest cover is down to about 10 percent of the land area. High levels of under-employment, low per capita income, and extreme difficulties in meeting basic needs have been the consequence. Since hill areas account for three-fourths of the country, cultivation pressure has invariably risen in sloping areas, swidden/shifting agriculture is taking place under substantially shortened fallow cycles, and erosion has increased substantially. The "push" for migration from the north is therefore intensifying. 1.4 The Central Highlands, with Vietnam's lowest population density and last remaining intact forests with the high concentrations of high-value biodiversity, are presently experiencing population growth rates of between 6 to 8 percent per annum. Population migration, which had hitherto been controlled, has been "spontaneous" since 1989. Without a concerted effort to address the situation, the migration push from the north to these areas could result in severe environmental and social impacts. Not only valuable biodiversity, but rare forest ecosystems, will be adversely affected: the carbon sequestering effects of forests will be reduced, critical watersheds will be destroyed, and local climatic changes, increasingly being attributed to the above degradation processes, will intensify. Socially, serious disruption of ethnic minority livelihood could result. C. GOVERNMENT STRATEGY AND LEGAL FRAMEWORK 1.5 The Government of Vietnam's (GOV's) concern and priority it assigned to addressing natural resource and environmental degradation is expressed in a number of documents, legislation and programs. The most important of which is the Vietnam National Environmental Action Plan (VNNEAP), August 1995, which forms the basis for Vietnam's current and future activities in environmental matters. One of the four priority programs for natural resource management identified in the VNNEAP is upland forest conservation and management for biodiversity and watershed protection. In addition, 4 other documents describe in greater detail GOV's strategy on forest protection and biodiversity conservation - National Conservation Strategy (1984); Tropical Forestry Action Plan (1991); the National Plan for Environment and Sustainable Development (1991); and Vietnam Biodiversity Action Plan (1995). Within this framework a major emphasis is on protection of viable examples of all major forest ecosystems within a national system of protected areas (PAs) of national parks and nature reserves. Currently, 87 PAs covering some 1.08 million ha, have been designated. Government also recognizes that in addition to protection measures, the sustainability of the PA system Other key forest/forest land degradation sources include: (i) fuelwood consumption (widespread with scattered tree cutting); (ii) commercial logging (significantly reduced since 1991 with introduction of bans on export of roundwood and sawn timber from natural forests); and (c) fire damage.
 - 3 - requires addressing the reasons for dependence on forest encroachment--poverty and food insecurity. 1.6 A number of laws and regulations on forest resource use and protection exist. The most important is the 1991 Forestry Resource Protection and Development Act which established three categories of forest land (i) protection forest (critical watersheds and wetlands); (ii) special use forests (protected areas); and (iii) production forests. A number of Implementing Decrees to strengthen forest protection including PAs were also issued that, among other things, specify the management principles of each forest category; the separation of forest protection from production; disengagement of the role of forest enterprise; and allocation of forest land to local users. A noteworthy regulation is Decree 327, issued in 1992, which sets out guidelines for a 10-year program aimed to protect forests and develop denuded or barren forest lands. This program was launched in 1993 with a US$68 million equivalent budgeted in the first year and between US$ 50-60 million in subsequent years. Despite significant investments, the 327 Program has been criticized for being too broad in scope thus reducing the likelihood of significant impacts of any investments. To remedy this, Decree 556 was issued in 1995 to replace 327 and target assistance more effectively and narrowly to activities directly related to PA, protection forests, and buffer zones. A number of other socio-economic programs have also been introduced since 1992. These include Program 120 for employment promotion and programs to fight hunger and poverty including nutrition, literacy, and subsidies or provision of basic goods. However, these have mainly bypassed the more remote districts and have not been implemented in conjunction with forest protection. 1.7 Although the 327/556 programs have contributed to the overall strengthening of forest protection, the current PA system still suffers from the following: (i) weak enforcement; (ii) shortage of staff, (iii) inadequate investments, and (iv) lack of influence on land use and people living in areas adjacent to the PAs (or buffer zone). Moreover, the absence of a comprehensive plan (i.e., management plan) to guide protection, management, and use of the PA has led to inefficient use of scarce human and financial resources. Although national parks and some nature reserves have management plans, they either are out-of-date or lack implementation detail and clarity. In addition, population growth and in-migration into areas surrounding PAs have increased the demands on limited resource base. Furthermore, the population in the buffer areas tends to be extremely poor. Balancing PA conservation and the need to improve the livelihood of the buffer zone population will require implementation of innovative conservation strategies and closer collaboration between various levels of government and between government staff and local people. D. INSTITUTIONAL FRAMEWORK 1.8 At the national level, the institutional framework for natural resource management is in a state of transition as organizational structures are adapted or created to deal with the demands for management of an increasingly market-oriented economy. The Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development (MARD) which has overall responsibility for the
 - 4 - natural resource sector was created in late 1995 by merging three former ministries (Agriculture and Food Industries, Forestry, and Water Resources Development). Although the structure has been established, the allocation of functions and responsibilities between departments are still being formulated. The merging of three sub-sectors, however, is expected to strengthen inter-linkages and multi-sector approaches to resource management. 1.9 Within MARD, the Forest Protection Department (FPD) is responsible for all protection activities, including those which take place in PAs. More specifically, FPD is charged with monitoring enforcement of law, policies and regulations concerning forest protection and management and transport of forest products. It also promotes public awareness, undertakes management audits, and administers some 8,000 field staff throughout the country. This structure is replicated throughout the country through Forest Protection Branches (FPB) at provincial and district levels. Provincial Agriculture and Forestry Departments and District Agriculture and Forestry Services provide service functions as opposed to the control functions of FPB. PAFDs are now being restructured as Provincial Agriculture and Rural Development Service (PARDS) combining agriculture, forestry, inland fisheries, and water resource activities. PA management at the field level is the responsibility of a Management Board headed by a Director which reports to the FPB in the case of nature reserves and jointly to FPB and FPD for national parks (since the national government provides some funding). A multitude of government agencies is responsible for activities in the buffer zone including PARDS, provincial Transport and Communications Department, and Department of Land Administration (DLA). Many of the PAs are adjacent to State Forest Enterprises (SFE) which are responsible for management of all production forest land and which also provide social service and community development functions. In this respect, SFEs overlap in function with local governments. The activities of all these entities are supposed to be coordinated by Provincial People's Committees. The effectiveness of such coordination varies between provinces. E. RATIONALE FOR IDA INVOLVEMENT 1.10 The importance of sustainable use of natural resources is one of the five key areas of emphasis in IDA's Country Assistance Strategy (CAS) for Vietnam discussed at the Board November 21, 1995 and in the progress report discussed December 23, 1996. The CAS also singled out deforestation as a critical issue for environmental action. Halting natural resources degradation is also a key element of the Bank's rural development strategy--Vision to Action: Rural Sector Strategy. Vietnam is one of 15 focal countries for implementation of this rural action plan. IDA's involvement in this sector began in 1992 through the development of the environment report, "Environmental Program and Policy Priorities for a Socialist Economy in Transition" (1995) and subsequent development of the VNNEAP. One major outcome of the IDA environment sector work is a recognition on the part of Government of the multidimensional and multisectoral nature of natural resource and environment degradation. Government has also recognized the need for outside assistance in addressing a number of difficult issues such as
 - 5 - community participation in development; land settlement, tenure rights and reform; state enterprise reform; and interagency coordination, all of which are critical issues in addressing loss of natural forests. The Association is assisting with macroeconomic management and external aid coordination and has carried out analytical work in support of the reform program with studies not only on the environment but also poverty, financial sector, transport, agricultural marketing and water resources management. It is against this background that Government has requested Bank assistance in strengthening current efforts in protecting forests. In addition, there are a number of small-scale pilot initiatives in many parts of Vietnam, supported by bilateral donors and NGOs (especially from Sweden, Germany, Denmark, Finland, UK, the Netherlands, Australia) from which lessons for larger scale replication can be learned particularly with regard to participatory community planning. IDA is in the best position to facilitate this process, which will involve not only project initiatives but also the resolution of key policy issues that are systemic in nature. F. LESSONS LEARNED 1.11 Lessons from Recent IDA Involvement In Vietnam. Other than the Irrigation Rehabilitation Project, which has been under implementation for less than two years, there is practically no experience to draw on for lessons learned in the natural resources/environment sector in Vietnam. However, IDA is involved in the implementation of eleven projects and a Structural Adjustment Credit in Vietnam, most of which are in the early stages of implementation. A second implementation review of IDA operations, carried out in September 1996, found the portfolio is performing satisfactorily considering the early stage of large donor project implementation. However, some implementation problems have emerged that are generic in nature and could become obstacles to implementation of the proposed project. Those that are relevant to this project include inadequate local budgetary allocations, non-codified procurement procedures, cumbersome fund flow arrangements, weak accounting and auditing capacity, and absence of project monitoring. To overcome these obstacles, a 21-point plan of action was agreed with Government which will be jointly monitored at regular intervals. These actions include more training in procurement and project management of project staff to be provided by the Resident Mission; issuance of implementing decrees related to budgeting for ODA-linked projects to ensure adequate and timely provision of counterpart funds; and regulations relating to national procurement procedures reflecting international practices. In addition, the proposed project has included significant project management technical assistance to assist in management, establishment of sound and efficient financial management practices, and establishment of a project monitoring and evaluation system. 1.12 Lessons From Bank/IDA Experience in Asia. The main lesson in PA management in Asia (and elsewhere) is that traditional park management of strengthening protection alone is insufficient and that there is a need to also address reasons for encroachment. Lessons from other Bank projects being prepared and implemented in the Asia region that integrate PA conservation with development (or ICDPs) are noteworthy
 - 6 - and were incorporated into project design. One set of prerequisites for successful project development concerns the need to have substantially developed a shared vision and objectives and the selection of appropriate sites and beneficiaries. These prerequisites have been established for the project through the VNNEAP process, IDA's policy and project workshops for forestry and natural resource management, and the project preparation process which has involved local governrnents from the start. Other lessons to be noted are the need for involvement of the local community in project preparation and implementation; for project preparation to be process driven; and for carrying out indicative planning exercise during preparation as a means of testing and validating project activities and approaches to community participation. 1.13 Lessons From Non-Bank ICDP Projects also indicate thatfirst, it is not enough for programs aimed at communities living adjacent to the PAs to be predicated on the assumption that improving incomes alone will relieve the pressure on conservation forest incursion. They must include PA protection as an explicit objective and there must be strong simultaneous demarcation and protection of the PA. Such a multi-faceted approach is needed because the self interest of buffer villagers must be taken into account in the joint protection process. Those that have been deriving benefits from the forest on their own account or on behalf of others (e.g., as agents of speculators and wildlife traders) will not readily agree to discontinue their past behavior unless (i) they are compensated for it or (ii) the cost of continuing their activities are made prohibitive. Second, joint consultation and participation of the affected villagers is necessary for successful joint forest protection and for sustainability in the protection process. In Vietnam, pilot initiatives under the 327 Program in a number of provinces (e.g., Yok Don National Park) have demonstrated the viability of allocating protection parcels at the fringe of PAs to local people with priority being given to the poor and landless. Assistance in longer term income improvement opportunities are given to secure their participation in joint protection. G. PROJECT PREPARATION PROCESS 1.14 Participatory Process. Preparation for the project has emphasized client ownership (particularly at the provincial and commune levels), local participation, and public consultation. A wide range of groups, organizations and individuals were consulted by the preparation team comprising government staff and local and international consultants. Four formal stakeholder workshops were held at various stages of preparation to finalize site selection; develop a shared vision and common objectives; and facilitate communications and exchange of views on project design and implementation arrangements. Three formal meetings were held with non-governmental organizations (NGOs) interested in the proposed project. Inputs from the grassroots level and project beneficiaries were solicited through provincial-level representatives; through participatory rural appraisal (PRA) and the indicative planning exercise carried out in two project communes; and through field visits by the preparation team and World Bank mission. Finally, numerous informal meetings were held to validate findings and disseminate information (see Annex 1 for more detail).
 - 7 - 1.15 Site Selection Criteria. In close consultation with provincial governments, MARD selected project sites from a list of 12 high "A" priority PAs identified in the Vietnam Biodiversity Action Plan. "A" level PAs are those containing biodiversity of international significance that need immediate protection. From that list, final selection was based on the following considerations: (i) high percentage of natural forests in the buffer zones to apply different management strategies; (ii) variation of threats and socioeconomic conditions to test different interventions; and (iii) strong interest and commitment of local authorities and communities to the objectives of the proposed project. As a result, two sites were selected, one in the Central Highlands where the threats are still low and manageable but where ethnic minorities dominate (Chu Mom Ray Nature Reserve or CMRNR) and the other in the lower central and southern provinces where the threats are severe and complex and multiple provinces fringe the PA [Cat Tien National Park (CTNP)].

PROJECT AREAS AND PARTICIPANTS 2.1 The project area includes Chu Mom Ray Nature Reserve (CMRNR), Cat Tien National Park (CTNP), and a surrounding area of agricultural and forestry land (buffer zone). Because an existing Dutch-funded project, Cat Tien National Park Conservation Project (CTNPCP)2, is addressing the strengthening of the protected area management, the project will support only buffer zone community development activities at CTNP, closely coordinated with the CTNPCP. (Annex 2 summarizes the interventions being applied by CTNPCP.) The project will support both PA protection and buffer zone activities at CMRNR. Buffer zone has been defined as a continuous band of those communes adjacent to the PAs of CTNP and CMRNR. The buffer zone also includes additional contiguous communes within 3 kilometers (km) of the PA in which human population may present an actual or potential threat to biodiversity conservation. This definition was adopted because the commune is the smallest administrative unit in the Vietnamese administrative system through which project activities can be effectively managed. 2.2 CMRNR is located in Kon Tum Province and currently covers an area of approximately 48,658 ha. It is proposed that the boundaries of CMRNR would expand under the project to include a total area of 57,500 ha based on further surveys. CTNP is comprised of 3 PAs in Dong Nai, Lam Dong and Binh Phuoc Provinces totaling 74,319 ha--Nam Cat Tien National Park, Cat Loc Nature Reserve, and Tay Cat Tien Nature Reserve, respectively. These 3 PAs will be managed as one national park based on a recent decision by GOV. The buffer zone for CTNP has a population of approximately 170,000 people in 30 communes and two district towns. Two communes in Dak Lak Province are included in the CTNP project area as they are adjacent to Cat Loc Nature Reserve. The buffer zone for CMRNR has approximately 20,000 people in 7 communes and 1 district town. (Table 2.1). Subcomponent (a): Community Development Planning. 2.9 The main objective of this subcomponent is to establish, for each project commune, the capacity and conditions for implementing a participatory planning process and prepare a CAP that will include an agreement between PA management and the commune. It will support the application of participatory rural appraisal (PRA) methods to identify essential social support services and associated activities such as land allocation, access to essential health and education services, and rural development interventions. BENEFITS 5.1 The main benefits of the project would be (a) the protection of invaluable biodiversity in the two PAs; (b) more effective management of natural forests in the buffer zone; (c) improvements in the socio-economic well-being of buffer zone communities; and (d) improvements in the institutional and administrative capacity of GOV. Beyond providing for the conservation of biodiversity, the project would broaden the focus of PA management planning, improve fire and poaching control, and improve staff efficiency and effectiveness. It would provide a base for public support for the PAs and would provide for technical review, administrative and financial services necessary for quality control, accountability, integration, and overall timeliness of project implementation. More importantly, the project would provide a new model for improved PA management and establish more participatory organizational processes that could be expanded to other ecologically significant areas in Vietnam. 5.2 Biodiversity Benefits. Although the value of the biodiversity in the PAs have not been quantified, these two PAs have been ranked as containing biodiversity of global importance through the Vietnam Biodiversity Action Plan exercise. CTNP harbors the only known surviving population of Javan rhinoceros, Rhinoceros sondaicus, in mainland Southeast Asia as well as several other internationally endangered species such as the white-winged wood duck, Cairina scutulata and Siamese crocodile, Crocodylus siamensis. It also supports some of the largest remaining examples of intact lowland dipterocarp and lagerstroemia/dipterocarp forests present in Vietnam. Although less is known about the biodiversity of CMRNR, preliminary surveys indicate that it supports a significant number of species which are under threat. Thirty-eight percent (29 species) of the Reserve's mammal fauna, for example, including the tiger Panthera tigris, douc langur Pygathrix nemaeus, white-cheeked gibbon Hylobates leucogenys and Asian black bear Ursus thinus, are considered to be either nationally or internationally endangered. CMRNR is also a high priority site for development as possible Indochinese transfrontier PA with Lao PDR and Cambodia which would increase the protection of wildlife that migrates through the three countries. 5.3 Economic Benefits. Economic analysis was undertaken for the rural development activities in the buffer zone. Because economic benefits are interdependent, conventional economic rates of return calculations were made on an aggregated basis by (a) adding up the incremental costs for infrastructure (irrigation and rural roads) and the "technology transfer" investments on the farm (in food crops, agro-forestry, cash crops and livestock); and (b) combining the production benefits of the subcomponents in such a way as to ensure that there would be no "double counting". Production benefits from the irrigation subcomponent can be analyzed separately (its economic rate of return or ERR is 15 percent). However, for the other production benefits (primarily rainfed yield and cropping density improvements), only those from technology transfer through
 - 31 - extension/credit assistance are included. The production benefits and transport cost savings associated with the road subcomponent were not included, while costs were. Based on these conservative assumptions, the ERR for the combined inivestments is 13 percent (see Annex 15 for details and sensitivity analysis). This figure includes the benefits from project investments that accrue outside the buffer zone communes. If the non-buffer area benefits were to be left out, an ERR of eight percent would be the result. If benefits were to be delayed by a year, the overall ERR would be nine percent. Given the above, and because the project includes significant biodiversity benefits which cannot be quantified, the overall ERR for the project is thus likely to have been understated. 5.4 The ERRs are calculated from financial farm models8 with adjustments for net taxes and the shadow pricing of family labor at the market rate. The calculations exclude the costs for technical assistance, land allocation, social support and project management because these costs cover more than the buffer zone subcomponents and any attempt to allocate them between buffer zone and non-buffer zone would be arbitrary. Excluded benefits, which are difficult to quantify, are those arising from (a) more sustainable land use practices and forest cover retention leading to decreased erosion/sedimentation and greater water availability downstream, and (b) the spill-over effects from the reduction of unemployment or underemployment due to increased income generation. 5.5 Financial Benefits. For a project which relies on improving the income and livelihood status of buffer households to secure their joint cooperation in forest protection, the financial rates of return (FRR) for these households will have to be high enough to motivate active participation. For subsistence or food staple crops, the incremental financial returns to the family labor effort is an important indicator of such an incentive. The improved technologies to be introduced (for various systems of paddy production and for maize and mung beans) will increase the returns per labor day from levels close to the market unskilled wage rate (about Dong 11,000/day) in the "without project" case to levels ranging from Dong 12,000 to 27,000/day in the "with project" case. 5.6 For cash crops, incremental financial returns would vary according to the types of buffer zone households, their farm endowment and location, and the market opportunities. In accessible areas with relatively good basaltic soils in the CTNP buffer zone (especially parts of Lam Dong and Dong Nai provinces), credit availability (from VBA&RD or a community revolving fund), together with project assistance in organizing farmers could enable households to achieve incremental FRRs ranging from 20 to over 75 percent. This would cover rainfed farming of annual crops (ranging from improved rice, maize, mulberry, or sericulture) and livestock to the introduction of irrigation to permit the cultivation of high yielding variety rice, hybrid maize and coffee. In less well endowed farms, extension service and subsistence credit assistance could help farmers through critical cash-short months and thus enable them to at least grow enough food 8 Farm models can be found in the project file.
 - 32 - (i.e., upland rice and maize) for subsistence before they can afford to produce high value cash crops.. 5.7 In the generally less accessible CMRNR buffer zone, where extensive barren land exists, an extension package, which includes the planting of multi-purpose fodder trees (to permit farmers to harvest leaves for livestock feeding in the dry season) would significantly improve livestock productivity and farm income. In some areas close to rubber plantations or sugar mills, opportunities exist for the introduction of raw material cash crops like rubber and sugar, the FRR of which are approximately 14 percent and 20 percent respectively. In some degraded forest areas, agroforestry (with a FRR of about 13 percent) may be an option. For the many poor and often hungry households in the less accessible forested buffer areas, employment opportunities provided under the forest protection contracts (to manage and protect allocated parcels of protection forests) may be the only source of cash income for these labor surplus, high poverty areas. In any case, the raising of buffer zone incomes would mean that buffer households would be more responsive to public awareness or extension programs and hence be more receptive to a change in the lifestyle that accepts greater responsibility for maintenance of the natural resources. 5.8 Fiscal Impact and Cost Recovery. The fiscal impact of the project on the Government will be minimal. Of the total project cost (net of taxes) of US$ 29.5 million, GOV's total contribution would only be about US$2.9 million. For example, GOV's net of tax contribution for infrastructure investment (about US 0.6 million or about 7 % of total project investment cost for both irrigation and roads) is small compared with the total capital expenditure GOV has historically (1991-95) allocated for irrigation (US$448 million) and transport/communications (US$892 million). In any case, on-farm costs and O&M costs for tertiary irrigation facilities would be borne by the beneficiaries through the contribution of their labor. GOV's contribution of nearly US$0.3 million for agricultural support services cannot be considered to be inordinate. To operate and maintain the US$3.1 million requirement for Social Support Grants under the project (100 percent IDA financing), Government needs to commit only about US$ 0.3 million to operate and maintain the social infrastructure to be developed under the project. Communities are required to provide a minimum of 10 to 25 percent. contribution as well. Finally, since GOV counterpart funding is also likely to be drawn from funding for existing programs (Decree 327/556 programs or Government's Hunger Eradication and Poverty Alleviation Program), the project can be considered as a means of ensuring that expenditures for these programs are efficiently used. SUSTAINABILITY 5.14 Project sustainability will be enhanced by the following interventions: (i) development of institutional and human resource capacity to implement conservation programs; (ii) development of ownership and commitment at commune and village to project objective of protecting critical forest resources and biodiversity; and (iii) development of incentives and alternative livelihood opportunities to reduce pressure on the PA. Furthermore, as the fiscal impact on the project is not inordinate (para 5.8), post project period sustainability is not expected to be a problem. The long-term sustainability of CMRNR and CTNP will depend to a large extent on a shared responsibility in PA conservation between MARD, provincial and local governments, and village communities residing around the PAs. Therefore, participatory planning, including land allocation and boundary demarcation, assuring appropriate market incentives, development and promotion of 'alternative livelihood opportunities, and the

Such a participatory approach will also serve to reduce the risk of choosing wrong investments under the project. 5.15 Sustainability will also depend on how effective is the design of the project and how cost effectively can the project activities be implemented. Care has been taken in designing the project to ensure that key ingredients of success has been incorporated (see para 5.14 above). Duplication has been avoided wherever possible (e.g., no separate investment/development support is being established for rubber, cotton or sericulture where existing state enterprises or agencies already exist). PROJECT RISKS 5.16 The project should be seen as an experiment being undertaken in very challenging circumstances. Many of the project interventions are innovative and "pilot" in nature and therefore could be considered highly risky. However, project activities were built upon processes that have been demonstrated in other locations in Vietnam and elsewhere in the region and tested in two project communes during the preparation process. The approach also emphasized greater involvement of local communities and use of existing support services and processes to deliver project goods and services. A high level of institutional support will "pilot test" these measures and make any modifications needed to enhance local effectiveness. 5.17 A major risk is increasing population pressure due to spontaneous and Government sponsored planned migration into the project area. Project activities have taken measures to minimize unplanned migration through PA boundary demarcation, land allocation in the buffer zone to secure land tenure, and better enforcement using joint protection contracts as well as strengthening protection measures. It has been demonstrated elsewhere in Vietnam that allocation of secure long-term title to land can, among other things, reduce the opportunity for in-migration. Although current GOV policy favors planned migration as a means of ensuring orderly labor mobility and equal access to economic opportunity, there is recognition of the need to limit migration into the project buffer zone areas to ensure long-term sustainability of the PA. The provincial governments have provided written assurances that no new Economic Zones will be established in the project area. 5.18 Another risk is that, despite receiving project benefits, existing local communities will fail to support the project's conservation objective, but will continue to press demands for remaining forest resources in the PA and surrounding buffer zone. The main

Improving the social well-being of the residents in the buffer zone communities adjoining the Protected Areas (PA) of Cat Tien National Park and Chu Mom Ray Nature Reserve is an important tool to secure local commitment to their protection. The buffer zone communes, especially households nearest to the PA, tend to be poorer and are also likely to be indigenous ethnic minorities. The Social Support Grants (SSG) program will provide small- scale grants to local communities to finance environmentally sustainable economic activities that contribute to a reduction in land-use pressures and in extraction of protected resources from the PA. In addition, SSG program will strike a balance in social support -- to empower and improve the social well-being of the relevant community and ensure that the vulnerable groups, which is the most critical to forest protection, are not left out. Experiences from Vietnam and other countries indicate that programs targeting development of the most vulnerable groups alone often do not achieve their objectives since solutions to their problems invariably involve the community (village/hamlet and commune) at large. 2. The CAP will have, among other things, social support activities prioritized with respect to what is important to the commune. These activities are likely to be communal in nature and/or be social infrastructure-related such as: * activities which improve access to basic services of education, health or potable water supplies (e.g., adding to or repairing of schools, health posts, community activity buildings, and completion of electricity connections); * activities that improve social and environmental awareness (e.g., health training, biodiversity and conservation awareness promotion) * activities which increase food security (ranging from assistance to poor households for food/subsistence production, introduction of proper sloping agriculture technologies to stabilize farm incomes, to establishment of community storage facilities); * services which can provide more equitable access to economic opportunities, especially for the poorer segment of the community (e.g., productive activities which cannot be funded through the VBA&RD or other commercial banks because of lack of collateral, agricultural field days, and marketing facilities); * services which ensure sustainability of community development efforts (e.g., training in organizing and managing community revolving funds); * activities which foster the retention of cultural traditions especially for indigenous ethnic minorities (cottage industry promotion, language and cultural training for the young)

The analysis above focuses on direct costs due to buffer zone interventions. Additional project costs such as technical assistance for land allocation, and social and technical support services are not included in the economic analysis. If these were to be added, the economic rate of return would drop, although these costs are relatively minor. Also excluded from the ERR calculations are those costs incurred through project management. To include these would require the attribution of project overheads between forest management and buffer zone development--an exercise that is considered to be quite arbitrary and is therefore not attempted. Some benefits are also excluded. First, forest protection and the promotion of more sustainable land use practices will enhance water retention, decrease sedimentation, and generally benefit downstream water users. Furtherrnore, in the project area, the additional income created are expected to have a multiplier effect in reducing the current level of unemployment or underemployment. Inclusion of these benefits would likely increase the ERR significantly. Financial Analysis 7. Financial Benefits. For a project which counts on improving the income and livelihood status of buffer households to secure their joint cooperation in forest protection, the financial rates of return for these households will have to be high enough to motivate active participation. For subsistence or food staple crops, the incremental financial returns to the family labor effort is an important indicator of such an incentive. The improved technologies to be introduced (for various systems of paddy production and for maize and mungbeans) will improve the returns per labor day from levels close to the market unskilled wage rate (about VND 11,000- 12,000/day) in the "without project" case to levels ranging from VND 12,000-27,000/day in the "with project" case, as summarized below: Food Staple Crop Without Project With Project VND/Labor Day Summer wetland paddy (new) 27,241 Autumn wetland paddy (new) - 22,574 Uplanid paddy 10,556 20,617 Shifting (Swidden) paddy 5,106 7,938 Upland maize 13,178 17,893 Upland mungbeans 10,910 12,256 Except for rice (paddy) under shifting cultivation (usually involving ethnic minority households), the imputed net income per labor day (i.e., opportunity cost for family labor) is roughly equivalent to the market wage for unskilled labor (assuming that jobs are available). Under the project, at full development, the returns to labor will be significantly higher than the market wage rate, except possibly for mungbeans grown under rainfed conditions. 8. For cash crops, incremental financial returns would essentially vary according to the types of buffer zone households, their farm endowment and location, and the market opportunities. In accessible areas with relatively good basaltic soils in the CTNP buffer zone
 - 83 - Annex 15 Page 5 of 5 (especially parts of Lam Dong and Dong Nai provinces), credit availability (from VBA&RD or a community revolving fund) together with project assistance in organizing farmers (through the development of the Commune Action Plan), could enable households to achieve incremental financial rates of return (FRRs) ranging from 20 to 75 percent (supporting tables are in the project file). This would be applicable to the rainfed farming of annual crops (ranging from improved rice, maize, mulberry or sericulture) and livestock, as well as to the introduction of irrigation to permit the cultivation of high yielding variety rice, hybrid maize, and coffee. In less well endowed farms facing less favorable market access, extension service and subsistence credit assistance could help farmers through critical cash-short months and thus enable them to at least grow enough food (i.e., upland rice and maize) for family subsistence as a prelude to introducing the production of high value cash crops.. 9. In the generally less accessible CMRNR buffer zone, where extensive barren land exists, an extension package which includes the planting of multi-purpose fodder trees (to permit farmers to harvest leaves for livestock feeding in the dry season) would significantly improve livestock productivity and farm income. In some areas close to rubber plantations or sugar mills, opportunities exist for the introduction of raw material cash crops like rubber and sugar, the FRR of which are approximately 14 percent and 20 percent respectively. In some degraded forest areas, agroforestry (with a FRR of about 13 percent) may be an option. For the many poor (and often hungry) households in the less accessible forested buffer areas, employment opportunities provided under the forest protection contracts (to manage and protect allocated parcels of protection forests) may be the only source of cash income for these labor surplus, high poverty areas. In any case, the raising of buffer zone incomes would mean that buffer lhouseholds would be more responsive to public awareness or extension programs and hence be more receptive to a change in the lifestyle that accepts greater responsibility for maintenance of the natural resources. 10. The project was subject of an Environmental Review carried out by the Environmental Protection Center (EPC), which is part of the Vietnam Institute of Tropical Technology and Environmental Protection under the Ministry of Science, Technology and Environment. The purpose of the Review was two-fold: (a) to consider the potential environmental impacts of activities and developments to be supported under the project; and, (b) to identify any existing or planned developments in the vicinity of the project areas having the potential to adversely affect the sustainability or effectiveness of the project. The review was based on initial drafts of the project preparation documents, project site inspections and discussions with relevant National, Provincial and District Government agencies. Potential Environmental Impacts of Project Activities 2. The Project was assessed as having generally positive environmental impacts through activities designed to improve protection and management of natural resources. However, three aspects of the project were identified as having some potential adverse environmental impact potential: (a) the Chu Mom Ray Nature Reserve (CMRNR) infrastructure development program; (b) small-scale irrigation developments; and, (c) rural road developments. These were subject to additional consideration. (a) CMRNR Infrastructure Development Program. The potential direct impacts were found to be minor and connected solely with the construction phase. The main risks are minor soil erosion, minor drainage impairment and hydrological impacts associated with inappropriate disposal of excavated materials and excess concrete associated with fords and culverts. All of these impacts canl be adequately controlled by inclusion of suitable provisions in the contract specifications (such specifications have been formulated in the Project Implementation Manual) combined with effective construction supervision to ensure that the specifications are observed. Potential indirect impacts could also arise due to the improved access into the Parks and Nature Reserves for landless people, hunters and poachers provided by the upgraded roads although it was conceded that this had to be balanced against the benefits that improved access would provide to management and staff of the Park. The balance was assessed as favoring upgraded access. lIncursionis and illegal exploitation are already occurring, even withi very poor access. The improved access may make things marginally easier for encroachers but it will much more significantly improve the capacity of forest rangers to detect and control these encroachments; (b) Upgrading of rural roads. Direct environmental impact potentials arise during the construction phase due to soil erosion, drainage impairment and inadequate disposal of excavated materials. Similar to the CMRNR infrastructure improvement, these issues will be addressed through the inclusion of suitable specifications in the contract documents and adequate construction supervision. Potential indirect impacts could arise due to increased encroachment resulting from development of new roads in the project areas. The recommended solution to this problem is exclude new road developments from funding eligibility under the project. Only rehabilitation of existing roads will be financed under the project;
 - 85 - Annex 16 Page 2 of 3 (c) Irrigation Sub-projects. Potential adverse impacts include: waterlogging of soils; increased incidence of water-borne and water-related diseases; increases in the incidence of agricultural pests and diseases resulting from the elimination of dry season die-back and the creation of a more humid microclimate; increased pollution of surface and groundwater from fertilizers and agricultural biocides; and, adverse water quality and biological impacts due to in-stream activities such as weir/dam construction or rehabilitation, river bank rehiforcement and bridge, ford or culvert construction. The significance of these potential impacts is directly proportional to the at-ea of irrigable land to be developed, the nature of the existing land use in the areas to be developed and the nature of the irrigation offtake (i.e. weir or reservoir). By these criteria, the impact potentials of the proposed developments are very small. Approximately half of the area to be developed will be rehabilitation of existing small schemes. The maximum incremental increase in irrigable area is only about 280 ha; all areas are already being cropped so there will be no significant change in land use; and no new weirs or reservoirs will be constructed. New irrigation developments will all be less than 400 ha in area and most of the offtakes are weirs having limited downstream impact potential. Four (Dak Can, Da Lay, Dak Lan and Dak Kar) involve on-stream storage but the diversion levels will be very small (e.g. for the largest of these four schemes, the peak water demand is likely to be in the order of 0.24 cumecs). All schemes are significantly less than 2,500 ha in area which is a guideline used by several environmental agencies in the Asia region for determining whether or not an environmenital impact assessment is required. As an additional level of protection, the Project Implementationi Manual includes a pro- forma Initial Environmental Screeninig report to provide a basis for determininig the acceptability of new irrigation developments. Potential Impacts of Activities in Surrounding Areas on the Project 3. Wide-ranging investigations and consultations with Provincial and local government officials identified three major external developments having potential to impact on the project: (a) tree crop developments in the Central Highlands; (b) water resources developments in the Dong Nai River Basin; and, (c) forest management activities by State-owned Forestry companies. (a) Tree Crop Developments in the Central Highlands. In recent years, substantial areas of "barren lands" in the Central Highlands have been converted from grassland to tree crops, mainly coffee. Additional tree crop developments are likely to occur in the future although alternative crops such as rubber and horticultural crops, may be favored over coffee. Provided these developments are confinied to areas outside Nature Reserves- and are restricted to true barren lands (i.e. areas which have already been cleared or otherwise degraded) they should present no significanit threat to the project development areas or to nature conservation values in genieral. In fact, these developments should support the objectives of the project insofar as they will help increase rural incomes and alleviate poverty, permit productive use of the barren lands and reduce the pressure to clear new lands including land inside Nature Reserves and State Forests. It is in recognitioni of the potential social and economic benefits of such crops that the Agricultural Support Services sub-component will include extension and demonstration of tree crops such as rubber. Nevertheless, there remains a residual albeit small risk of a land development boom in the Central Highlanids region which could adversely affect nature reserves and forested areas and contlict with the objectives of the project. The project includes a forest
 - 86 - Annex 16 Page 3 of 3 management sub-component which provides for increased forest protection through Forest Protection contracts between households and the Provincial Forest Protection Branch. If successful, these should provide quite a strong level of protection against external land conversion pressures. (b) Water resources development opportunities in the Dong Nai River Basin. Development opportunities in the Dong Nai River Basin have recently been the subject of a major river basin management plan funded by the Japanese International Cooperation Agency. The major direct threat to the project areas related to plans to establish multi-purpose darn developments in the immediate vicinity of the Nam Cat Tien - Cat Loc area which would have resulted in inundation of parts of Cat Tien National Park. However, the management plan recommended that these developments should not proceed due to their adverse environmental impact potentials and poor economic rates of return. The Dai Ninh hydropower development, well upstream of Cat Tien, is due to commence construction within the next two years but, based on the eiivironmental impact study for that development, it should have no significant impact on the environment in the vicinity of Nam Cat Tien - Cat Loc. (c) Forest Management Operations by State Forest Enterprises. These were subject of a technical evaluation study as part of project preparation. The study noted that continuation of present unsustainable cutting of natural forests under jurisdiction of the State Forest enterprises represents an important threat to forest protection efforts in the project area, particularly the Nam Cat Tien - Cat Loc area. The study predicted that, in 20 to 30 years, the Nam Cat Tien and Cat Loc forests are likely to be the only natural forests of any consequence left in the southern part of Vietnam. The forest management and joint forest protection activities being supported under the project are clearly important to maintaining these resources in the long term however, but the study also recommended additional protection could be provided if forest plantation establishment on degraded forest lands was promoted to provide long term timber supplies alternative to the remnants contained in the national parks and nature reserves. Support for such investments is beyond the scope of the proposed project but a contribution will be made to this longer term objective by supporting pilot activities to restructure a small number of adjoining State Forest Enterprises. If these enterprises can be placed on a more financially sustainable footing, the incentive to more rationally manage forest resources in their reserve areas will be significantly increased.

doc.abstracts: The overall objective of the Forest Protection and Rural Development Project is to assist Vietnam to protect and manage natural forests with high biodiversity. More specifically, the main development objectives are: 1) to effectively protect Cat Tien National Park (CTNP) and to effectively protect and manage the Chu Mom Ray Nature Reserve (CMRNR); 2) to effectively manage the remaining natural forests outside the protected areas (PA) but within the buffer zone of CTNP and CMRNR; 3) to reduce dependency on CTNP and CMRNR for subsistence and cash income; and 4) to strengthen capacity of the government to effectively design, implement, and monitor ICDPs. To achieve these objectives, three main components and their subcomponents comprise the project. The Protected Area Management for CMRNR Component provides for revising the existing Management Plan for CMRNR in two phases; implements the revised Management Plan including boundary demarcation, introduces PA management programs, supports basic infrastructure, and supplies basic equipment; implements selected research studies and surveys; formulates and implements a public awareness campaign in the CMRNR; develops programs to encourage and manage nature tourism in the PA and buffer zone; and trains PA staff to run the intensified conservation management and visitor programs. The Buffer Zone Development Component has six subcomponents: community development planning, land allocation involving land use planning at the commune level and helping to prepare cadastre maps and the issuance of land use certificates; social support in the form of "food security," basic infrastructure and activities to strengthen local social and cultural institutions; agricultural support services (extension, technology transfer, and public awareness); forest protection and management; and rural infrastructure improvement, including expanding irrigation systems, upgrading roads, and improving road access. The third component, Project Management and Institutional Development, includes strengthening institutional capacity at all levels to implement project activities and sustain project interventions.
